    b(n−1)/2≡(bn) mod n.b^{(n-1) / 2} \equiv\left(\frac{b}{n}\right) \bmod n . b(n−1)/2≡(nb​)modn.

Let ppp denote any of the primes p1,p2,…,prp_{1}, p_{2}, \ldots, p_{r}p1​,p2​,…,pr​. Prove that there exists a b∈Bb \in Bb∈B such that

    (bp)=−1 and b≡1 mod n/p\left(\frac{b}{p}\right)=-1 \quad \text { and } \quad b \equiv 1 \bmod n / p (pb​)=−1 and b≡1modn/p

    and deduce that nnn is not an Euler pseudo-prime to this base bbb. Hence prove that nnn is not an Euler pseudo-prime to the base bbb for at least half of all the relatively prime residue classes b mod nb \bmod nbmodn.

    (a) How does coding theory apply when the error rate p>1/2p>1 / 2p>1/2 ?

    (b) Give an example of a code which is not a linear code.

    (c) Give an example of a linear code which is not a cyclic code.

    (d) Give an example of a general feedback register with output kjk_{j}kj​, and initial fill (k0,k1,…,kN)\left(k_{0}, k_{1}, \ldots, k_{N}\right)(k0​,k1​,…,kN​), such that

    (kn,kn+1,…,kn+N)≠(k0,k1,…,kN)\left(k_{n}, k_{n+1}, \ldots, k_{n+N}\right) \neq\left(k_{0}, k_{1}, \ldots, k_{N}\right) (kn​,kn+1​,…,kn+N​)=(k0​,k1​,…,kN​)

    for all n⩾1n \geqslant 1n⩾1.

    (e) Explain why the original Hamming code can not always correct two errors.

    (ii) Describe the Rabin-Williams scheme for coding a message xxx as x2x^{2}x2 modulo a certain NNN. Show that, if NNN is chosen appropriately, breaking this code is equivalent to factorising the product of two primes.

    (i) Consider a network with node set NNN and set of directed arcs AAA equipped with functions d+:A→Zd^{+}: A \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}d+:A→Z and d−:A→Zd^{-}: A \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}d−:A→Z with d−⩽d+d^{-} \leqslant d^{+}d−⩽d+. Given u:N→Ru: N \rightarrow \mathbb{R}u:N→R we define the differential Δu:A→R\Delta u: A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}Δu:A→R by Δu(j)=u(i′)−u(i)\Delta u(j)=u\left(i^{\prime}\right)-u(i)Δu(j)=u(i′)−u(i) for j=(i,i′)∈Aj=\left(i, i^{\prime}\right) \in Aj=(i,i′)∈A. We say that Δu\Delta uΔu is a feasible differential if

    d−(j)⩽Δu(j)⩽d+(j) for all j∈Ad^{-}(j) \leqslant \Delta u(j) \leqslant d^{+}(j) \text { for all } j \in A d−(j)⩽Δu(j)⩽d+(j) for all j∈A

    Write down a necessary and sufficient condition on d+,d−d^{+}, d^{-}d+,d−for the existence of a feasible differential and prove its necessity.

    Assuming Minty's Lemma, describe an algorithm to construct a feasible differential and outline how this algorithm establishes the sufficiency of the condition you have given.

    (ii) Let E⊆S×TE \subseteq S \times TE⊆S×T, where S,TS, TS,T are finite sets. A matching in EEE is a subset M⊆EM \subseteq EM⊆E such that, for all s,s′∈Ss, s^{\prime} \in Ss,s′∈S and t,t′∈Tt, t^{\prime} \in Tt,t′∈T,

    (s,t),(s′,t)∈M implies s=s′(s,t),(s,t′)∈M implies t=t′\begin{array}{lll} (s, t),\left(s^{\prime}, t\right) \in M & \text { implies } & s=s^{\prime} \\ (s, t),\left(s, t^{\prime}\right) \in M & \text { implies } & t=t^{\prime} \end{array}(s,t),(s′,t)∈M(s,t),(s,t′)∈M​ implies  implies ​s=s′t=t′​

    A matching MMM is maximal if for any other matching M′M^{\prime}M′ with M⊆M′M \subseteq M^{\prime}M⊆M′ we must have M=M′M=M^{\prime}M=M′. Formulate the problem of finding a maximal matching in EEE in terms of an optimal distribution problem on a suitably defined network, and hence in terms of a standard linear optimization problem.

    [You may assume that the optimal distribution subject to integer constraints is integervalued.]

    1−H(2δ)⩽lim inf⁡n→∞α(n,nδ)⩽1−H(δ)1-H(2 \delta) \leqslant \liminf _{n \rightarrow \infty} \alpha(n, n \delta) \leqslant 1-H(\delta) 1−H(2δ)⩽n→∞liminf​α(n,nδ)⩽1−H(δ)

    H(η)=−ηlog⁡2η−(1−η)log⁡2(1−η)H(\eta)=-\eta \log _{2} \eta-(1-\eta) \log _{2}(1-\eta) H(η)=−ηlog2​η−(1−η)log2​(1−η)
